title: MD: Monowar Hossain
text:
I am a graduate student at the University of Dhaka, pursuing an M.S. in Applied Statistics & Data Science. My academic work is driven by a focus on using advanced statistical methodologies to solve real-world problems, particularly within the realms of public health and sociodemographic analysis.
Currently, I serve as the Joint Secretary of the Dhaka University Research Society (DURS). In this role, I enjoy mentoring others in statistical software and coordinating initiatives that promote data-driven inquiry across campus.



Public Health Analytics: Investigating non-communicable diseases and health inequities using large-scale survey data (e.g., BDHS).
Spatial Statistics: Applying geospatial modeling and machine learning to understand environmental and regional disparities.
Modern Modeling: Exploring Bayesian inference, causal inference, and big data analytics.





Joint Secretary: Dhaka University Research Society (DURS).
Data Specialist: Dhaka University Runners Community (DURC).
Technical Training: Facilitating workshops in R, STATA, and SPSS for students and professionals.

title: Attending ICASDS 2025: Unlocking New Possibilities in Data Science
text:
I recently had the opportunity to attend the International Conference on Applied Statistics and Data Science (ICASDS 2025), held at the Nabab Nawab Ali Chowdhury Senate Bhaban, University of Dhaka.
The theme of the conference, “Data-driven Solutions: Unlocking New Possibilities,” perfectly aligns with my current academic focus in my M.S. program. Over the course of December 28-29, I engaged with global experts and fellow researchers through a variety of programs:

Key Highlights:

Keynote & Plenary Sessions: Gained insights into the future of global data science trends.
Student Poster Competition: Observed innovative research from peers, which was highly motivating for my own work on geospatial health inequities.
Networking: Connected with statisticians and data scientists during the invited paper sessions.

Attending this conference was a significant milestone in my graduate journey, providing fresh perspectives on how applied statistics can solve complex real-world problems.
